Austrian Chancellor Karl Nehammer announced his resignation as chancellor and leader of the conservative People’s Party following failed attempts to form a coalition government. Talks with the Social Democrats collapsed after the liberal Neos party withdrew, with Nehammer citing “destructive forces” in the Social Democratic Party as a key factor. He refused to endorse policies he believed would harm Austria’s economic competitiveness.  

Social Democratic leader Andreas Babler called the breakdown a missed chance to address Austria's challenges, including a 3.7% budget deficit exceeding EU limits. The stalemate follows the far-right Freedom Party’s electoral victory in September, with most parties unwilling to partner with them.

article_preview: The World Bank is set to approve a USD 20 billion indicative lending package for Pakistan – a pioneering 10-year initiative to protect its funded projects from political transitions and focus on six t...
reference_summary:
The World Bank is poised to approve a groundbreaking USD 20 billion lending package for Pakistan under the "Pakistan Country Partnership Framework 2025-35." This long-term, 10-year initiative is designed to safeguard projects from political instability, focusing on six key areas: reducing child stunting, combating learning poverty, improving climate resilience, decarbonizing the environment, expanding fiscal space, and boosting private investment for productivity. These sectors enjoy broad political support and are expected to remain unaffected by government changes, ensuring consistency throughout the period, which will include multiple elections.

The package will consist of concessional loans from the International Development Association (IDA) totaling USD 14 billion, while the remaining USD 6 billion will be provided through the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). Additionally, the World Bank's private lending arms, the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), will contribute another USD 20 billion in private sector loans, bringing the total value to USD 40 billion.

This shift in strategy marks a move away from smaller, scattered investments to more substantial, targeted initiatives aimed at fostering long-term growth and stability. The framework will be finalized after approval on January 14, and the World Bank's Vice President for South Asia, Martin Raiser, is expected to visit Islamabad shortly afterward.

Union Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw stated that the draft rules for the Digital Personal Data Protection (DPDP) Act aim to balance regulation with innovation, ensuring citizen rights are protected while fostering the growth of startups. The government released these draft rules for public consultation until February 18. Vaishnaw emphasized that the rules are in line with the Act passed by Parliament and are designed to safeguard privacy, particularly for children. For example, platforms will need verifiable parental consent before children can create accounts.

The rules include graded penalties, with micro, small, and medium enterprises facing lighter penalties for minor breaches, while larger companies like Big Tech will face stricter consequences. The penalties could be as high as Rs 250 crore for severe breaches. There is also a provision for entities to voluntarily disclose breaches, which, if accepted by the Data Protection Board, could shield them from further legal action.

The final rules are set to be presented to Parliament during the monsoon session, and businesses will have two years to adapt to the new regulations. Vaishnaw assured that the rules would consider national interests and citizen rights, especially for data processing overseas, and that the media's rights would remain unaffected.

reference_summary:
The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) has proposed several tax reforms in its pre-Budget Memorandum for 2025. These include offering tax benefits for promoting climate change mitigation strategies to support India’s environmental goals and economic growth. ICAI also recommended creating a separate section in income tax returns for income from shares and securities, simplifying capital gains provisions, and rationalizing tax rates for cash credits and unexplained investments. 

The institute suggested a special tax regime for partnership firms and LLPs, as well as a more straightforward income tax return process. It also proposed simplifying the process for non-residents transferring immovable property to residents. Other recommendations include a more efficient grievance redressal system, alignment of tax deduction rates, and a mandatory time limit for appeal disposal. Additionally, ICAI advocates for extending the deadline for filing belated returns until March 31 of the assessment year. These reforms aim to foster economic growth, simplify the tax process, and enhance tax compliance.

Essential food items like meat and eggs remain expensive due to supply issues such as adverse weather. New government tariffs on imported goods, especially from China, are also contributing by raising production costs.

The housing sector continues to see pressure with rental costs up 5.2% year-over-year. Although the Federal Reserve recently lowered its benchmark interest rate, inflation remains above its 2% target, potentially delaying further cuts. The stock market reacted negatively, with major indices dropping, and consumers are reducing discretionary spending. Economists anticipate inflation could remain elevated, possibly prompting the Fed to reconsider its interest rate strategy to stabilize the economy.

Delhi has traditionally seen assembly polls in a single phase. we have deliberately kept polling on a Wednesday so more people come out to vote , like we did in Maharashtra," Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar said at a press conference .
